I remember reading ‚ÄúWhen Breath Becomes Air‚Äù, which is written by a neurosurgeon who was diagnosed with a terminal illness. Not suggesting that‚Äôs the case for you, but it offers a unique perspective. It varies from ‚ÄúThe last lecture‚Äù in the sense that it‚Äôs a bit more about perspective than following the authors story as he works towards his last lecture, but also a good book.

comment: THE book I always read to make my old self feel better is ‚ÄúA Tree Grows in Brooklyn‚Äù about a girl coming of age in poverty in the early 20th century.     (When a bite of pickle is a luxury, my own circumstances are‚Ä¶just fine, actually.)  Another fun one is ‚ÄúForever Amber‚Äù a sort-of romance featuring Amber, irrepressible and ambitious in 1660s England. It‚Äôs not super raunchy but Amber is prone to affairs and marriages despite always wanting to be with her first love. It‚Äôs fun to root for Amber even when she does dumb stuff!  When my Grandma was quite blind, I got her a little Walkman (yes, was a while ago) with audiobooks of All Creatures Great And Small. Nothing raunchier than small dogs stuck together, and having a warm friendly voice telling stories, I thought, would be a comfort. Grandma hated it and used it for listening to cowboy music, so your mileage will vary.  Also, tell her I say hi! I‚Äôm 60+, freshly divorced and in a new place, too; plus the depression and anxiety are imperfectly controlled with drugs. It took about a year of dragging myself to coffee shops, used book stores, and garage sales before I finally stopped emitting social anxiety like a pigpen cloud.  I wish her good luck in getting out there! It helps!
author: Betty  Smith

comment: A Man Called Ove by Fredrik Backman. It's about a grumpy elderly man definitely struggling with loneliness after his wife dies, he feels like he's lost his place in his neighborhood. He does attempt to end his life fyi but it's not gruesome, more despondent. A young family moves in and starts interacting with him, and he also begrudgingly acquires a cat. It flashes between present day and his early years meeting his wife. Very poignant and ultimately hopeful, finding a new lease in life in his later years. There are two film adaptations, one in Swedish with the same title and more recently A Man Called Otto with Tom Hanks.   Remarkably Bright Creatures by Shelby Van Pelt. It has three perspectives - an elderly woman whose son was lost at sea, she works cleaning the aquarium. A young man (maybe 20s?) who is drifting through life and launches a poorly organized journey to discover who his father is. And Marcellus, an octopus at the aquarium who routinely sneaks out of his tank and forms a friendship with the woman.
author: Fredrik Backman, Henning Koch

comment: A number of Wally Lamb books deal with mental illness. I‚Äôve read all of the titles below. Hope this helps.   	1.	‚ÄúI Know This Much Is True‚Äù 	‚Ä¢	The novel follows Dominick Birdsey as he navigates life while caring for his paranoid schizophrenic twin brother, Thomas. It delves into themes of identity, trauma, and the complexities of mental illness.  	2.	‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Come Undone‚Äù 	‚Ä¢	Dolores Price struggles with obesity, depression, and self-destructive behavior following a traumatic childhood event. The story explores her journey towards self-acceptance and mental health recovery.  	3.	‚ÄúWe Are Water‚Äù 	‚Ä¢	The novel tells the story of Annie Oh, an artist dealing with past trauma and mental illness as she prepares for her second marriage. It examines family dynamics, secrets, and the impact of untreated mental health issues.  	4.	‚ÄúThe Hour I First Believed‚Äù 	‚Ä¢	Caelum Quirk and his wife, Maureen, cope with the aftermath of the Columbine High School massacre, which leads Maureen to struggle with PTSD. The novel addresses the long-term effects of trauma on mental health.  Some others I‚Äôve read in recent years by different authors:  	5.	‚ÄúEleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine‚Äù by Gail Honeyman 	‚Ä¢	The novel centers on Eleanor Oliphant, a socially awkward woman with a traumatic past, as she begins to confront her loneliness and mental health issues.  	6.	‚ÄúSharp Objects‚Äù by Gillian Flynn 	‚Ä¢	A psychological thriller about Camille Preaker, a journalist with a history of self-harm and mental illness, who returns to her hometown to investigate a series of murders.
author: Wally Lamb

comment: Okay there are some self help books that are really good. I used to read them alot. Sorry, i cant recall only one, maybe cuz tha stayed "a monk who sold his ferrari"  Lately i have been going through biographies, I think they are the real deal, like it has so many  perspectives, new insight and mainly the dreamers, the power to believe. It has really helped me alot. There is "shoe dog, by Phil Knight, Steve Jobs by Isaacson, Into the wild.( but in general every book has th to offer, that makes us to search for sth more than ourselves) Starting my day with some of these reads, gives a headstart to my day, i am not in that negative mindset, so a little more confident. Its still hard for me to express myself but i know thats a great start. And also try incorporating some exercises in your routine, you will be amazed by the benefits and try putting yourself more out there in social platforms or even with other friends- a little at a time.

comment: The first book that comes to mind is "How to Win Friends & Influence People" by Dale Carnegie. Yes, it's an older book and some of the examples used are a bit dated, but there's some good information to help with confidence and talking with strangers.  The negative comments I hear about this book are because the tactics are often used by sales people to seem friendly and caring to improve their chances of making a sale. So I would recommend that you use the tips genuinely and not to try and sell someone something.

comment: [**Rising Strong**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/23317538-rising-strong)  ^(By: Bren√© Brown | 336 pages | Published: 2015 | Popular Shelves: non-fiction, self-help, nonfiction, psychology, personal-development | )[^(Search "Rising Strong")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Rising Strong&search_type=books)  >The physics of vulnerability is simple: If we are brave enough often enough, we will fall. The author of Daring Greatly and The Gifts of Imperfection tells us what it takes to get back up, and how owning our stories of disappointment, failure, and heartbreak gives us the power to write a daring new ending. Struggle, Bren√© Brown writes, can be our greatest call to courage, and rising strong our clearest path to deeper meaning, wisdom, and hope.  ^(This book has been suggested 114 times)  [**The Gifts of Imperfection**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7015403-the-gifts-of-imperfection)  ^(By: Bren√© Brown | 138 pages | Published: 2010 | Popular Shelves: non-fiction, self-help, psychology, nonfiction, personal-development | )[^(Search "Gifts of Imperfection")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Gifts of Imperfection&search_type=books)  >New York Times best-selling author and professor Bren√© Brown offers a powerful and inspiring book that explores how to cultivate the courage, compassion, and connection to embrace your imperfections and to recognize that you are enough. > >Each day we face a barrage of images and messages from society and the media telling us who, what, and how we should be. We are led to believe that if we could only look perfect and lead perfect lives, we'd no longer feel inadequate. So most of us perform, please, and perfect, all the while thinking, What if I can't keep all of these balls in the air? Why isn't everyone else working harder and living up to my expectations? What will people think if I fail or give up? When can I stop proving myself?In The Gifts of Imperfection, BrenÈ†Çrown, PhD, a leading expert on shame, authenticity and belonging, shares what she's learned from a decade of research on the power of Wholehearted Living--a way of engaging with the world from a place of worthiness.In her ten guideposts, Brown engages our minds, hearts, and spirits as she explores how we can cultivate the courage, compassion, and connection to wake up in the morning and think, No matter what gets done and how much is left undone, I am enough, and to go to bed at night thinking, Yes, I am sometimes afraid, but I am also brave. And, yes, I am imperfect and vulnerable, but that doesn't change the truth that I am worthy of love and belonging.  ^(This book has been suggested 99 times)  ***  ^(128692 books suggested | )[^(I don't feel so good.. )](https://debugger.medium.com/goodreads-is-retiring-its-current-api-and-book-loving-developers-arent-happy-11ed764dd95)^(| )[^(Source)](https://github.com/rodohanna/reddit-goodreads-bot)

He does attempt to end his life fyi but it's not gruesome, more despondent. A young family moves in and starts interacting with him, and he also begrudgingly acquires a cat. It flashes between present day and his early years meeting his wife. Very poignant and ultimately hopeful, finding a new lease in life in his later years. There are two film adaptations, one in Swedish with the same title and more recently A Man Called Otto with Tom Hanks.   Remarkably Bright Creatures by Shelby Van Pelt. It has three perspectives - an elderly woman whose son was lost at sea, she works cleaning the aquarium. A young man (maybe 20s?) who is drifting through life and launches a poorly organized journey to discover who his father is. And Marcellus, an octopus at the aquarium who routinely sneaks out of his tank and forms a friendship with the woman.
author: Fredrik Backman, Henning Koch

comment: *The Sociopath Next Door* by Martha Stout  *The Boy Who Was Raised as a Dog* by Perry and Szalavitz is mostly about trauma, but there is a case study in there about a sociopathic murderer and how his upbringing almost certainly led him to be that way. It‚Äôs Chapter 5: The Coldest Hart but it will make more sense with the context and background given in the other chapters.   They have another book *Born For Love* which is all about how people develop empathy starting in infancy and how that process can be derailed. So it‚Äôs not specifically focused on sociopaths, but sociopathy is characterized by lack of empathy and conscience so it‚Äôs very much related. There‚Äôs a whole spectrum of case studies from a girl adopted from a neglectful Romanian orphanage to a teenage rapist.

title_raw: The Girl with all the Gifts
comment: Books that don‚Äôt feel like fiction:  ‚ÄúThe Good Earth‚Äù by Pearl S Buck. If you are interested in history or China it is a masterpiece  ‚ÄúShogun‚Äù a perfect work of historical fiction about an English sailor who lands in early Japan. (Tw - starts with a scene of pretty awful violence)  ‚ÄúThe Absolutely True Diary of a Part Time Indian‚Äù (partially autobiographical, with hilarious illustrations), YA (tw - traumatic childhood)  ‚ÄúThe Hate U Give‚Äù (YA) a black girl growing up in a wonderful supportive family witnessed her friend getting shot, and has to deal with the social ramifications  If you‚Äôd like a mystery:  ‚ÄúThe Dry‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Lost Man‚Äù by Jane Harper. Both take place in the deserts of Australia and involve family drama/trauma. (tw - traumatic childhood)  If you‚Äôd like a historical fiction YA book that‚Äôs will make you feel better:  ‚ÄúThe War that Saved my Life‚Äù about a girl and her brother who were evacuated from London during WWII, from an abusive home to a kind home.  If you‚Äôd like a book that‚Äôs YA and a little harder to make sense of (like a puzzle) until it all becomes clear:  ‚ÄúChallenger Deep‚Äù by Neil Schusterman. A gentle book About a boy dealing with the beginnings of schizophrenia.   More fictional books:  ‚ÄúCirce‚Äù is really good book about loneliness that is fiction because it is about Gods and Goddesses of Greece, but is more focused on emotions. Slow and deep.  ‚ÄúThe Girl with all the Gifts‚Äù - an intellectual zombie story that reads like a fast-paced first person story. Hard to put down!  ‚ÄúThe Bone Clocks‚Äù really a series of short stories all tied together by how the characters are related to each other and how they deal with these evil humans who are acting like psychic vampires. Amazing book. Audio book is even better. To see if you‚Äôd like it read the short story version ‚ÄúSlade House‚Äù.  Anything by Octavia Butler. It‚Äôs speculative fiction but they don‚Äôt feel like fantasy/sci-fi. They are focused on the characters and their relationships, and especially on power dynamics in society.  Extremely Fiction  ‚ÄúGideon the Ninth‚Äù this book has people who had no happy childhoods, but is amazingly well written. The tagline is ‚Äúlesbian necromancers in space‚Äù, but it‚Äôs more about the relationship between two women who fucking hate each other and are trying to get away from each other.  ‚ÄúShades of Grey‚Äù by Jasper Fforde my favorite dystopia! About a boy who lives in a world where your status is determined by by how much color you can see. He falls in love with a grey, a lowest class woman, who shows him more than he wanted to see about his society. Makes you think about a lot of things in new ways.
verified_title: The Girl with All the Gifts

title_raw: Feel the Fear ... and Do It Anyway
comment: Here are a few books that have made a real difference for me and might offer you some valuable insights and strategies:  ["The Six Pillars of Self-Esteem"](https://amzn.to/42VQQcM)¬†by Nathaniel Branden - This book dives deep into what self-esteem really is and how to build it from the ground up. Branden breaks it down into six practices that you can work on, like living consciously and self-acceptance. It's a bit of a read, but it's packed with exercises and practical advice that can make a big difference.  ["Daring Greatly"](https://amzn.to/3UUwwH8)¬†by Bren√© Brown - Bren√© Brown talks about vulnerability and how it's actually a strength, not a weakness. Her book really changed the way I look at myself and my interactions with others. It's about embracing who you are, flaws and all, and stepping into the world with more courage and confidence.  ["Feel the Fear ... and Do It Anyway"](https://amzn.to/3IcLY9L)¬†by Susan Jeffers - This book is a classic for a reason. It's all about facing the fears that hold you back and developing the confidence to get past them. Jeffers provides practical tools and exercises to help you change your mindset and take control of your life.  ["Mindset: The New Psychology of Success"](https://amzn.to/3OWmOQp)¬†by Carol S. Dweck - Dweck introduces the concept of "fixed" vs. "growth" mindsets and how they impact our lives, including our self-esteem. Understanding that abilities and intelligence can be developed was a game-changer for me. It's a powerful read that can help you see challenges in a new light and boost your confidence in learning and growing.  ["Unfu\*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life"](https://amzn.to/3TcZtNa)¬†by Gary John Bishop - If you're looking for something more straightforward, this book cuts right to the chase. It's a no-nonsense guide to getting over your mental hurdles and taking action towards the life you want. It's motivating and can give you that kick to start making changes.  Each of these books offers something unique, from understanding the foundations of self-esteem to practical steps for building confidence and facing fears. It's okay to feel stuck sometimes, but with the right tools and a bit of effort, you can move forward. I hope these books help you as much as they've helped me. Hang in there, and remember that seeking help is a huge step forward in itself.
verified_title: Feel the Fear and Do It Anyway
author: Susan  Jeffers

comment: The Road by Cormac MaCarthy.   A father and son are surviving in the post apocalyptic wasteland. Everyone they come across is potentially a cannibal or bandit. The world is grey and black, no life.  There's nothing to live for except their love for each other and the hope they can find other people who also want a community of goodness.  It's a story of a little flame in complete darkness. I felt like having a kid after finishing it if that helps you see the restored faith in humanity.  MaCarthy dedicated the book to his son which made the dialogue between the characters all that more intriguing.  Alert: graphic scenes of horror.

comment: **Notes From The Underground**. A short fiction (but it being so is of little consequence) of intense rambling by an overly self aware, self-destructing, neurotic. The book itself is a memoir of sorts, so by its nature it is self aware. But it is also aware in the sense that it is a story about his life as he tells it, and he tells it in layers of chaotic peelings of his consciousness. Which makes it oddly philosophical, and wonderfully psychological. The character constantly lies to you and admits to doing so while revelling in his own sick way, in the fact he is being an unreliable narrator. It is nihilism at its most desperate hour. My favourite book. I learn something new about myself every time I read it. Which is quite a wonderfully awful thing to do. It is your worst parts of yourself on display smashing you in your face as you read. What it is like to be on the outside of normal society, underground.  Aside from that, I occasionally like flipping through **The Art of Motorcycle Maintenance**, but I wouldn't call it a face hugger of a book. Self-helpy in a sort of laissez faire way. **The Stranger** by Camus, was addicting and self helpy for my existential depression, but is not non-fiction. **The Selfish Gene** by Richard Dawkins was incredible, the insights it gives to evolutionary psychology were paradigm shifting for me. Took me too long to get over how pretentious he is and just read his work, which is actually quite good.    Honestly the most addicting books for me have been fiction. There are great books like The Red Queen by Matt Ridley about the evolutionary psychology of sexual selection, or other books about evolution and the "why" behind being a social species, which is self help to me, but they just don't suck me in the same way as.... Things Fall Apart, or The Bell Jar... simple easy fiction reads, that deal with not wanting to live and the nature of being human. I do love Russian literature fiction like Dostoevsky, not exactly light reading, and its quite off-putting for most with how pretentious its fans like myself, are, but oh well.   But for Non-fiction I love total suck fests like Night by Elie Wiesel, Ordinary Men: Reserve Police Battalion 101 by Christopher R. Browning, The Rape of Nanking by Iris Chang, Unit 731 by Alistair Rogers, and The Gulag Archipelago by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. Just absolute PTSD inducing jaw dropping brutality. Why? I have no idea. I may have visited the Anne Frank House too young and its my way to reconcile that shattering trip. Oh I'm rambling quite well now, toodles. Oh and I do not recommend these last books.
author: Iris Chang

comment: [**Wintergirls**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5152478-wintergirls)  ^(By: Laurie Halse Anderson | 278 pages | Published: 2009 | Popular Shelves: young-adult, ya, contemporary, fiction, mental-health | )[^(Search "Wintergirls")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Wintergirls&search_type=books)  >Lia and Cassie are best friends, wintergirls frozen in fragile bodies, competitors in a deadly contest to see who can be the thinnest. But then Cassie suffers the ultimate loss‚Äîher life‚Äîand Lia is left behind, haunted by her friend's memory, and feeling guilty for not being able to help save her. > >In her most powerfully moving novel since Speak, award-winning author, Laurie Halse Anderson explores Lia's struggle, her painful path to recovery, and her desperate attempts to hold on to the most important thing of all‚Äîhope.  ^(This book has been suggested 11 times)  [**Sharp Objects**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/18045891-sharp-objects)  ^(By: Gillian Flynn | 254 pages | Published: 2006 | Popular Shelves: mystery, fiction, thriller, crime, mystery-thriller | )[^(Search "Sharp Objects")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Sharp Objects&search_type=books)  >Fresh from a brief stay at a psych hospital, reporter Camille Preaker faces a troubling assignment: she must return to her tiny hometown to cover the unsolved murder of a preteen girl and the disappearance of another. For years, Camille has hardly spoken to her neurotic, hypochondriac mother or to the half-sister she barely knows: a beautiful thirteen-year-old with an eerie grip on the town. Now, installed in her old bedroom in her family's Victorian mansion, Camille finds herself identifying with the young victims‚Äîa bit too strongly. Dogged by her own demons, she must unravel the psychological puzzle of her own past if she wants to get the story‚Äîand survive this homecoming. > >Librarian's Note: this is an alternate cover edition - ISBN 10: 0307341550 (ISBN 13: 9780307341556)  ^(This book has been suggested 116 times)  [**Kept in the Dark**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/13506596-kept-in-the-dark)  ^(By: Penny Hancock | 352 pages | Published: 2012 | Popular Shelves: thriller, fiction, mystery, crime, suspense | )[^(Search "Kept in the Dark")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Kept in the Dark&search_type=books)  >Greenwich, Londra. In un freddo pomeriggio di febbraio, Sonia apre la porta di casa a Jez, 15 anni, un amico del figlio. Il ragazzo vorrebbe vedere un raro disco di vinile, pensa di restare qualche minuto e andare via. Non uscir√† pi√π. Con una folle progressione geometrica, un passo dopo l‚Äôaltro, Sonia fa in modo che Jez non lasci la casa sul fiume, fino a quando non scoprir√† di esserne prigioniero, di non poter chiedere aiuto. La sola possibilit√† che gli resta√® trovare un modo per convivere con lei, con quella donna che lo considera una cosa sua, un oggetto da proteggere, da custodire. Non ha altra strada se non venire a patti con la sua carceriera: del resto, chi lo cercherebbe mai in quella splendida, vecchia dimora in riva al Tamigi? Chi sospetterebbe di unamoglie e madre esemplare, che non ha mai mostrato alcun segno di squilibrio? La casa sul fiume √® la storia di un‚Äôossessione, di uno smarrimento che affonda le sue radici nei meandri pi√π oscuri della psiche. Ed √® la storia di una donna reale e vera come solo il dolore sa esserlo: perch√© la sua solitudine, i suoi ricordi, i suoi moventi parlano al cuore di ognuno di noi.  ^(This book has been suggested 1 time)  [**Wasted: A Memoir of Anorexia and Bulimia**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/46815.Wasted)  ^(By: Marya Hornbacher | 298 pages | Published: 1997 | Popular Shelves: non-fiction, memoir, nonfiction, memoirs, psychology | )[^(Search "Wasted")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Wasted&search_type=books)  >Why would a talented young woman enter into a torrid affair with hunger, drugs, sex, and death? Through five lengthy hospital stays, endless therapy, and the loss of family, friends, jobs, and all sense of what it means to be "normal," Marya Hornbacher lovingly embraced her anorexia and bulimia‚Äîuntil a particularly horrifying bout with the disease in college put the romance of wasting away to rest forever. A vivid, honest, and emotionally wrenching memoir, Wasted is the story of one woman's travels to reality's darker side‚Äîand her decision to find her way back on her own terms.  ^(This book has been suggested 4 times)  [**Prozac Nation**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/227603.Prozac_Nation)  ^(By: Elizabeth Wurtzel | 368 pages | Published: 1994 | Popular Shelves: non-fiction, memoir, psychology, nonfiction, mental-health | )[^(Search "Prozac Nation")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=Prozac Nation&search_type=books)  >A harrowing story of breakdowns, suicide attempts, drug therapy, and an eventual journey back to living, this poignant and often hilarious book gives voice to the high incidence of depression among America's youth. A collective cry for help from a generation who have come of age entrenched in the culture of divorce, economic instability, and AIDS, here is the intensely personal story of a young girl full of promise, whose mood swings have risen and fallen like the lines of a sad ballad.  ^(This book has been suggested 13 times)  [**More, Now, Again: A Memoir of Addiction**](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/137918.More_Now_Again)  ^(By: Elizabeth Wurtzel | 336 pages | Published: 2000 | Popular Shelves: memoir, non-fiction, memoirs, addiction, nonfiction | )[^(Search "More, Now, Again")](https://www.goodreads.com/search?q=More, Now, Again&search_type=books)  >Elizabeth Wurtzel published her memoir of depression, Prozac Nation,  to astonishing literary acclaim. A cultural phenomenon by age twenty-six, she had fame, money, respecteverything she had always wanted except that one, true thing: happiness.  > For all of her professional success, Wurtzel felt like a failure. She had lost friends and lovers, every magazine job she'd held, and way too much weight. She couldn't write, and her second book was past due. But when her doctor prescribed Ritalin to help her focus-and boost the effects of her antidepressants -- Wurtzel was spared. The Ritalin worked. And worked. The pills became her sugar...the sweetness in the days that have none. Soon she began grinding up the Ritalin and snorting it. Then came the cocaine, then more Ritalin, then more cocaine. Then I need more. I always need more. For all of my life I have needed more...  >More, Now, Again is the brutally honest, often painful account of Wurtzel's descent into drug addiction. It is also a love story: How Wurtzel managed to break free of her relationship with Ritalin and learned to love life, and herself, is at the heart of this ultimately uplifting memoir that no reader will soon forget.  ^(This book has been suggested 2 times)  ***  ^(167270 books suggested | )[^(I don't feel so good.. )](https://debugger.medium.com/goodreads-is-retiring-its-current-api-and-book-loving-developers-arent-happy-11ed764dd95)^(| )[^(Source)](https://github.com/rodohanna/reddit-goodreads-bot)

comment: Ursula Le Guin‚Äôs books frequently touch on these themes, if you‚Äôre open to fantasy/sci fi. Her father was an anthropologist and her books often consider how culture and ritual shape us in daily life, as well as the value of the seemingly mundane.  In particular, I would say *Tales from Earthsea* and some of the stories in *The Birthday of the World*, especially the story ‚ÄúSolitude‚Äù and the very end of the novella ‚ÄúParadises Lost‚Äù.  Some of the Japanese healing novels also touch on these themes. *What You Are Looking For Is In The Library* by Michiko Aoyama is my personal favorite, and features different stories from intertwined characters who find new enjoyment and connection in simple things due to savvy recommendations from an unusual librarian.

comment: I recommend it strongly I will say it takes multiple readings to get all these hidden themes (which I argue makes it even a stronger book) and the last one about God and Adam was only after my third read through and reading elements of the bible which greatly influence McCarthy.   I will say it is a darker book so please be prepared for some scenes which require a small intermission or reflection (nothing extreme or too incredible graphic or sexual).   Also I would strongly suggest to look up any words you might not understand for with McCarthy's Blood Meridian and The Road he choose each word with care and compassion almost like he was setting each word on a printing press plate.  Also here is the link to the audio book which too me is the best audiobook production hands down. The narrator is bloody amazing and perfect.
